headline: Door To Door: Ohio’s U.S. Senate candidates take the debate stage
author: Nick Castele
sentences: She criticized him, for instance, for accepting campaign contributions from the political action committee of West Virginia Sen. Joe Manchin, the red-state Democrat who stood athwart President Joe Biden’s Build Back Better spending bill.

Analysis
You could be forgiven if, as the Democratic Senate candidates kicked off their debate yesterday, you realized that you'd momentarily forgotten there were Democrats running at all.
Politically, of course, it makes perfect sense that most GOP candidates would cast themselves in a senate-race season of “The Apprentice.” Trump won Ohio twice, and by a healthy margin.
That’s perhaps one reason so many candidates have donned the MAGA hat – figuratively, at least – in TV ads and campaign stops, as ably chronicled recently by NPR's Don Gonyea.
Morgan Harper, a former Consumer Financial Protection Bureau attorney who is mounting a left-lane challenge to Rep. Tim Ryan, kept the Niles congressman on the defensive.
Perhaps channeling the populism of his old boss, the late Rep. Jim Traficant, is Ryan’s only shot at getting this reddening state to beam him up to the U.S. Senate.
It fell to her to carry out the thankless task of throwing cold water on the still-simmering false claim that widespread voter fraud cost Trump the 2020 election.
When Kasler asked about the “slugfest” nature of the primary, Gibbons replied, “I want to point out to you it did not become a slugfest.
That’s because the Republicans have commanded the attention as they’ve tussled for support from thousands of Ohioans and one Floridian.
The polling winds are blowing against Biden, and historical precedent sets up the Democrats to lose their slipping grip on Congress.
The Mar-a-Lago primary is up in the air; former President Donald Trump has not anointed any of Ohio’s GOP contenders.
Meanwhile, the congressman largely stuck to his core message: that he’ll fight for workers and against China.
The debate did not feature a repeat of Mike Gibbons’ recent nose-to-nose confrontation with Josh Mandel.
Calling China the foe of Ohio manufacturing is a charge heard from both sides of the aisle.
Our Karen Kasler moderated Monday night’s showdown between the seven Republican hopefuls.

There were no punches thrown.”
There’s still time.
That’s at least the bet he seems to be making.
He no doubt had the general election in mind.
Back to the Democratic debate.
